elements.content: Heavy-metal ions and nitroaromatic substances are highly toxic and harmful to human health and the ecological environment. It is an urgent issue to selectively detect and capture these toxic substances. By introducing the triazole ligand to the π-conjugated aromatic carboxylate system and borrowing the organic template open framework idea, a stable fluorescent framework [Me2NH2]4­[Zn6(qptc)3­(trz)4]·6H2O (1) (H4qptc = terphenyl-2,5,2′5′-tetra­carboxylic acid, trz = 1,2,4-triazole) has been successfully synthesized, which features Zn4(trz)2 chain-based 3D anionic structure with channels filled by [Me2NH2]+ cations. It is worth noting that the material exhibits selective adsorption and recyclable detection of heavy-metal Cr3+ ion in aqueous solutions, which may be the synergy from the metal charge, bond ability of metal ions to carboxylate oxygen atom, and soft–hard acid–base properties. Furthermore, it can selectively sense of 2,4,6-trinitrophenol with a large quenching coefficient K sv of 2.08 × 106 M–1.
elements.clean_text: Heavy-metal ions and nitroaromatic substances are highly toxic and harmful to human health and the ecological environment. It is an urgent issue to selectively detect and capture these toxic substances. By introducing the triazole ligand to the π-conjugated aromatic carboxylate system and borrowing the organic template open framework idea, a stable fluorescent framework [Me2NH2]4[Zn6(qptc)3(trz)4]⋅6H2O (1) (H4qptc = terphenyl-2,5,2'5'-tetracarboxylic acid, trz = 1,2,4-triazole) has been successfully synthesized, which features Zn4(trz)2 chain-based 3D anionic structure with channels filled by [Me2NH2]+ cations. It is worth noting that the material exhibits selective adsorption and recyclable detection of heavy-metal Cr3+ ion in aqueous solutions, which may be the synergy from the metal charge, bond ability of metal ions to carboxylate oxygen atom, and soft-hard acid-base properties. Furthermore, it can selectively sense of 2,4,6-trinitrophenol with a large quenching coefficient K sv of 2.08 × 106 M-1.

elements.content: A stable fluorescent 3D anionic MOF with atn topology has been successfully synthesized, which is constructed by Zn4(trz)2 chain SBUs and π-electron rich qptc4− linkers. It displays selective visual sensing of heavy-metal Cr3+ ion in aqueous solutions, which can be recyclable, and a TNP contaminant with a large K sv value of 2.08 × 106 M−1.
elements.clean_text: A stable fluorescent 3D anionic MOF with atn topology has been successfully synthesized, which is constructed by Zn4(trz)2 chain SBUs and π-electron rich qptc4- linkers. It displays selective visual sensing of heavy-metal Cr3+ ion in aqueous solutions, which can be recyclable, and a TNP contaminant with a large K sv value of 2.08 × 106 M-1.

elements.content: Heavy-metal contaminants are becoming a pressing issue because of their high toxicity and bioaccumulation. Among the biologically relevant heavy-metal ions, a trace amount of Cr3+ is necessary and has a huge impact on the metabolism of carbohydrates, fats, proteins, and nucleic acids. The deficiency of Cr3+ can cause diabetes, atherosclerosis, and cardiovascular diseases. However, excess Cr3+ is still toxic and harmful to human health, which can incorporate with DNA and result in mutations and malignant cells. Chromium is abundantly used in industrial processes including, for example, electroplating, paint manufacturing, tanning, and steel fabrication. The improper handling of industrial waste containing chromium may generate contamination of soil and water sources, eventually harming the environment and human health. Moreover, 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP), as a kind of important chemical raw material, has been widely used in the fields of medicines, explosives, papermaking, and textile. However, it is highly toxic and may cause male infertility, anemia, and other severe health problems. Considerable efforts are being made to effectively detect heavy-metal Cr3+ ion and TNP. Compared with various analytical techniques, fluorescence detection possesses the advantage of portability, visualization, short response time, and high sensitivity, which has attracted increasing attention. DNA polyfluorophores, chalcogenides, and covalent organic polymers have been developed as fluorescent sensor to detect heavy-metal ions and nitroaromatics. However, their applications are confined by limited active sites, low stability, or difficulty with respect to regeneration. Therefore, it remains a challenge to explore stable, recyclable fluorescent materials for selective detection and capture of Cr3+ ion and TNP.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Heavy-metal contaminants are becoming a pressing issue because of their high toxicity and bioaccumulation. Among the biologically relevant heavy-metal ions, a trace amount of Cr3+ is necessary and has a huge impact on the metabolism of carbohydrates, fats, proteins, and nucleic acids. The deficiency of Cr3+ can cause diabetes, atherosclerosis, and cardiovascular diseases. However, excess Cr3+ is still toxic and harmful to human health, which can incorporate with DNA and result in mutations and malignant cells. Chromium is abundantly used in industrial processes including, for example, electroplating, paint manufacturing, tanning, and steel fabrication. The improper handling of industrial waste containing chromium may generate contamination of soil and water sources, eventually harming the environment and human health. Moreover, 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP), as a kind of important chemical raw material, has been widely used in the fields of medicines, explosives, papermaking, and textile. However, it is highly toxic and may cause male infertility, anemia, and other severe health problems. Considerable efforts are being made to effectively detect heavy-metal Cr3+ ion and TNP. Compared with various analytical techniques, fluorescence detection possesses the advantage of portability, visualization, short response time, and high sensitivity, which has attracted increasing attention. DNA polyfluorophores, chalcogenides, and covalent organic polymers have been developed as fluorescent sensor to detect heavy-metal ions and nitroaromatics. However, their applications are confined by limited active sites, low stability, or difficulty with respect to regeneration. Therefore, it remains a challenge to explore stable, recyclable fluorescent materials for selective detection and capture of Cr3+ ion and TNP.

elements.content: Porous metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have been utilized for radioactive waste capture, drug release, and heavy-metal ion sensing, because of their large surface areas, readily adjustable pore size, and functions, which makes MOFs super candidates for sensing. Fluorescent MOFs with π-electron rich aromatic ligands were initiated by Li and co-workers to sense electron-deficient nitroaromatics, which are reversible, rapid, and sensitive, but selective detection of one contaminant (nitro-explosives and heavy-metal ions) is still in infancy. Recently, only a few pyridine, amine, or hydroxyl group MOFs materials were reported to selectively detect TNP or metal ions (Hg2+/Pb2+), and the maximum quenching constant is at a magnitude of 105. Combination of rigid azoles with π-conjugated aromatic carboxylate ligands is an effective strategy to synthesize stable fluorescent materials because soft-acid (Zn ions) would coordinate with soft-base nitrogen donor ligands, forming stronger Zn–N bonds, as exemplified by zeolite framework ZIF-8 with exceptional thermal and chemical stability. Moreover, rod-shaped metal-azole SBUs can further enhance the stability of MOFs and prevent the structure from being interpenetrated. In addition, anionic MOFs can be constructed by borrowing the organic cationic template idea from traditional aluminosilicates, which potentially capture and detect metal cations through ion exchange.
elements.clean_text: Porous metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been utilized for radioactive waste capture, drug release, and heavy-metal ion sensing, because of their large surface areas, readily adjustable pore size, and functions, which makes MOFs super candidates for sensing. Fluorescent MOFs with π-electron rich aromatic ligands were initiated by Li and co-workers to sense electron-deficient nitroaromatics, which are reversible, rapid, and sensitive, but selective detection of one contaminant (nitro-explosives and heavy-metal ions) is still in infancy. Recently, only a few pyridine, amine, or hydroxyl group MOFs materials were reported to selectively detect TNP or metal ions (Hg2+/Pb2+), and the maximum quenching constant is at a magnitude of 105. Combination of rigid azoles with π-conjugated aromatic carboxylate ligands is an effective strategy to synthesize stable fluorescent materials because soft-acid (Zn ions) would coordinate with soft-base nitrogen donor ligands, forming stronger Zn-N bonds, as exemplified by zeolite framework ZIF-8 with exceptional thermal and chemical stability. Moreover, rod-shaped metal-azole SBUs can further enhance the stability of MOFs and prevent the structure from being interpenetrated. In addition, anionic MOFs can be constructed by borrowing the organic cationic template idea from traditional aluminosilicates, which potentially capture and detect metal cations through ion exchange.

elements.content: In our previous work, an anionic oxysulfide open framework material with organic template has exhibited high selectivity in sequestering heavy-metal ions from wastewater. As a continuous research work in fluorescent materials, introducing triazole ligand to π-conjugated aromatic carboxylate system and borrowing the organic template idea, we present herein a stable fluorescent MOF [Me2NH2]4­[Zn6(qptc)3­(trz)4]·6H2O (1) (H4qptc = ter­phenyl-2,5,2′5′-tetra­carboxylic acid, trz = 1,2,4-triazole), which features Zn4(trz)2-chains based 3D atn topological anionic structure with channels filled by [Me2NH2]+. This material exhibits good stability in pH from 2 to 10 aqueous solutions. Interestingly, it can selectively adsorb heavy-metal Cr3+ ion in aqueous solutions and fluorescently detect Cr3+ ion, which can be recyclable. Particularly, it displays selective visual sensing of TNP with a large quenching coefficient K sv of 2.08 × 106 M–1, higher than the reported maximum value of 5.10 × 105 in metal–organic frameworks.
elements.clean_text: In our previous work, an anionic oxysulfide open framework material with organic template has exhibited high selectivity in sequestering heavy-metal ions from wastewater. As a continuous research work in fluorescent materials, introducing triazole ligand to π-conjugated aromatic carboxylate system and borrowing the organic template idea, we present herein a stable fluorescent MOF [Me2NH2]4[Zn6(qptc)3(trz)4]⋅6H2O (1) (H4qptc = terphenyl-2,5,2'5'-tetracarboxylic acid, trz = 1,2,4-triazole), which features Zn4(trz)2-chains based 3D atn topological anionic structure with channels filled by [Me2NH2]+. This material exhibits good stability in pH from 2 to 10 aqueous solutions. Interestingly, it can selectively adsorb heavy-metal Cr3+ ion in aqueous solutions and fluorescently detect Cr3+ ion, which can be recyclable. Particularly, it displays selective visual sensing of TNP with a large quenching coefficient K sv of 2.08 × 106 M-1, higher than the reported maximum value of 5.10 × 105 in metal-organic frameworks.

elements.content: A mixture of H4qptc (0.040 g, 0.10 mmol), Zn­(OAc)2·6H2O (0.045 g, 0.20 mmol), 1,2,4-triazole (0.007 g, 0.10 mmol), DMF (4 mL), and H2O (2 mL) were stirred and adjusted to pH = 6 by dropwise addition of 8 M HNO3 solution, then sealed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless autoclave at 140 °C for 5 days. After it was slowly cooled to room temperature and filtrated, colorless cuboid block crystals of 1 were collected (yield of 85% based on Zn). Anal. Calcd (%) for C41H27N8O15Zn3 (1): C, 46.11; H, 2.55; N, 10.49. Found: C, 46.20; H, 2.25; N, 10.70. IR data (Figure S1, KBr pellet, cm–1): 3436 (s), 3129 (w), 2791 (w), 2477 (w), 1595 (s), 1379 (s), 1154 (s), 1078 (w), 852 (w), 782 (w), 677 (w). The crystal data are given in , whereas selected bond lengths and bond angles are given in Table S1.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis of [Me2NH2]4[Zn6(qptc)3(trz)4]⋅6H2O (1)

A mixture of H4qptc (0.040 g, 0.10 mmol), Zn(OAc)2⋅6H2O (0.045 g, 0.20 mmol), 1,2,4-triazole (0.007 g, 0.10 mmol), DMF (4 mL), and H2O (2 mL) were stirred and adjusted to pH = 6 by dropwise addition of 8 M HNO3 solution, then sealed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless autoclave at 140 °C for 5 days. After it was slowly cooled to room temperature and filtrated, colorless cuboid block crystals of 1 were collected (yield of 85% based on Zn). Anal. Calcd (%) for C41H27N8O15Zn3 (1): C, 46.11; H, 2.55; N, 10.49. Found: C, 46.20; H, 2.25; N, 10.70. IR data (Figure S1, KBr pellet, cm-1): 3436 (s), 3129 (w), 2791 (w), 2477 (w), 1595 (s), 1379 (s), 1154 (s), 1078 (w), 852 (w), 782 (w), 677 (w). The crystal data are given in , whereas selected bond lengths and bond angles are given in Table S1.

elements.content:
Crystal Data and Refinement Parameters for <bold>1</bold> compound 1 empirical formula C41H27N8O15Zn3 ρcalc (mg cm–3) 0.864 formula wt 1067.63 μ (mm–1) 1.495 cryst syst tetragonal F(000) 3752.0 space group P-42 1 m cryst size (mm) 0.3 × 0.26 × 0.2 a (Å) 26.6256(4) reflns 43449 b (Å) 26.6256(4) R int 0.0481 c (Å) 20.2942(6) T max /T min 1.0000/0.7823 α (deg) 90 data/params 12616/535 β (deg) 90 R 1 , wR 2  [I > 2σ (I)] 0.0480, 0.1312 γ (deg) 90 R 1,wR 2 (all data) 0.0551, 0.1371 V (Å3) 14387.1(5) Δρmax/Δρmin (eÅ–3) 0.61/–1.17 Z 8 Flack param 0.29(4)

R 1 = ∑||F 0| – |F c||/∑|F 0|

wR 2 = [∑w­(F 0 2 – F c 2)2/∑w­(F 0 2)2]1/2

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in a tetragonal noncentro-symmetrical space group P-421 m. The asymmetric unit of 1 consists of four crystallographic independent Zn­(II) atoms, one and a half of qptc4– ligands, two triazole molecules, and three free water molecules (a). Four Zn­(II) atoms, except for Zn(1) and Zn(3), localize in special positions (mirror plane) and thus have site occupancies of 1, 0.5, 1, and 0.5, respectively. Each Zn­(II) atom adopts a tetrahedron geometry, coordinated by two oxygen atoms from two qptc4– ligands and two nitrogen atoms from different triazole molecules. The Zn–O distances are in the range of 1.929–2.034 Å, whereas the Zn–N lengths are in the range of 2.01–2.07 Å. The L–Zn–L (LO, N) bond angles are in the scope of 93.4(4)–129.6(3)° (Table S1). Each carboxylate group adopts μ1-η1:η0 monodentate mode, and thus, the qptc4– ligands connect Zn­(II) centers to form a twisted H-shape (Figure S2). Four Zn­(II) atoms are alternately ligated together by μ1,2,4-bridging triazole ligands giving rise to an infinite wavy Zn4(trz)2 chain (c). The adjacent chains are further linked through two different directions of qptc4– ligands to form a 1D channel (9.89 × 11.22 Å2) along the c axis (d) and finally created a 3D anionic framework (b). The charge is balanced by the in situ-generated [Me2NH2]+ from the decomposition of DMF solvent, which is consistent with elemental analyses and TG analyses (Figure S3). Calculations with PLATON program reveals that the accessible pore volume of 1 is 8547.1 Å3 per unit cell volume 14387.1 Å3 (59.7% of the total volume). Each rod-shaped Zn4(trz)2 chain as SBUs is bridged by four terphenyl-carboxylates ligands, and each ligand is linked by four Zn4(trz)2 chain SBUs, thus forming a atn topological 3D framework with a 1D channel. For zigzag ladder SBUs, there are four four-connected nets (sra, irl, umr, and atn) depending on whether the SBUs are parallel or vertical. In sra net, all of the linked ladders are parallel while the ladders are twisty in irl net. However, the ladders are vertical to each other in atn and umr nets. Each ladder of 1 is slanted perpendicular to its four neighbors, and thus, the net of 1 is atn rather than sra, irl, or umr topology, which is rarely reported by the literature (Figure S4).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Description of Structure

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in a tetragonal noncentro-symmetrical space group P-421 m. The asymmetric unit of 1 consists of four crystallographic independent Zn(II) atoms, one and a half of qptc4- ligands, two triazole molecules, and three free water molecules (a). Four Zn(II) atoms, except for Zn(1) and Zn(3), localize in special positions (mirror plane) and thus have site occupancies of 1, 0.5, 1, and 0.5, respectively. Each Zn(II) atom adopts a tetrahedron geometry, coordinated by two oxygen atoms from two qptc4- ligands and two nitrogen atoms from different triazole molecules. The Zn-O distances are in the range of 1.929-2.034 Å, whereas the Zn-N lengths are in the range of 2.01-2.07 Å. The L-Zn-L (LO, N) bond angles are in the scope of 93.4(4)-129.6(3)° (Table S1). Each carboxylate group adopts μ1-η1:η0 monodentate mode, and thus, the qptc4- ligands connect Zn(II) centers to form a twisted H-shape (Figure S2). Four Zn(II) atoms are alternately ligated together by μ1,2,4-bridging triazole ligands giving rise to an infinite wavy Zn4(trz)2 chain (c). The adjacent chains are further linked through two different directions of qptc4- ligands to form a 1D channel (9.89 × 11.22 Å2) along the c axis (d) and finally created a 3D anionic framework (b). The charge is balanced by the in situ-generated [Me2NH2]+ from the decomposition of DMF solvent, which is consistent with elemental analyses and TG analyses (Figure S3). Calculations with PLATON program reveals that the accessible pore volume of 1 is 8547.1 Å3 per unit cell volume 14387.1 Å3 (59.7% of the total volume). Each rod-shaped Zn4(trz)2 chain as SBUs is bridged by four terphenyl-carboxylates ligands, and each ligand is linked by four Zn4(trz)2 chain SBUs, thus forming a atn topological 3D framework with a 1D channel. For zigzag ladder SBUs, there are four four-connected nets (sra, irl, umr, and atn) depending on whether the SBUs are parallel or vertical. In sra net, all of the linked ladders are parallel while the ladders are twisty in irl net. However, the ladders are vertical to each other in atn and umr nets. Each ladder of 1 is slanted perpendicular to its four neighbors, and thus, the net of 1 is atn rather than sra, irl, or umr topology, which is rarely reported by the literature (Figure S4).

elements.content: (a) Coordination environments of Zn (II), (b) view of 3D framework of 1 along c axis, (c) a rod-shaped [Zn4(trz)2] chain, and (d) 1D channel along c axis.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Coordination environments of Zn (II), (b) view of 3D framework of 1 along c axis, (c) a rod-shaped [Zn4(trz)2] chain, and (d) 1D channel along c axis.

elements.content: The phase purity of the samples 1 was confirmed by PXRD patterns. Most peak positions of simulated and experimental patterns are in good agreement with each other. To further investigate the stability of 1, it was immersed in different pH values aqueous solutions or water at 75 °C. The PXRD patterns indicated that the structure is retained after soaked in water at 75 °C and pH = 2–10 aqueous solutions (Figure S5), confirming the strong chemical stability, which is ascribed to the strong Zn–N bonds (triazole). TGA of 1 was performed at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1 to estimate the thermal stability in air. As shown in Figure S3, the first weight loss of 8.22% within 102 °C belongs to the loss of lattice water molecules. The second weight loss of 35.25% in the range of 102–400 °C is in agreement with the removal of triazole and qptc4– ligand, accompanied by the decomposition of the framework. The final residue of 15.01% is close to the percentage of zinc oxide (calcd 17.78%).
elements.clean_text:
Stability of 1 

The phase purity of the samples 1 was confirmed by PXRD patterns. Most peak positions of simulated and experimental patterns are in good agreement with each other. To further investigate the stability of 1, it was immersed in different pH values aqueous solutions or water at 75 °C. The PXRD patterns indicated that the structure is retained after soaked in water at 75 °C and pH = 2-10 aqueous solutions (Figure S5), confirming the strong chemical stability, which is ascribed to the strong Zn-N bonds (triazole). TGA of 1 was performed at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 to estimate the thermal stability in air. As shown in Figure S3, the first weight loss of 8.22% within 102 °C belongs to the loss of lattice water molecules. The second weight loss of 35.25% in the range of 102-400 °C is in agreement with the removal of triazole and qptc4- ligand, accompanied by the decomposition of the framework. The final residue of 15.01% is close to the percentage of zinc oxide (calcd 17.78%).

elements.content: The existence of [(CH3)2NH2]+ cations and uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen atoms inspires us to capture heavy-metal ions in aqueous solution. Samples of 1 were immersed in 10 mL of MCl x aqueous solutions (0.01 mol/L, M = Mg2+, Cd2+, Mn2+, Cs+, Hg2+, Cr3+, Al3+, La3+) for 24 h (Figure S6). It is noted that the color of crystals has grown green after immersing the samples in Cr3+ aqueous solutions, whereas that of other metal ions did not change. The PXRD patterns of the crystals soaked in different metal ions solutions are almost identical with that of original 1, indicating that the basic framework of 1 remains intact (Figure S7). EDS results showed the presence of these metal ions (except Cs+), which has been successfully encapsulated by 1 (Figure S8, 1–M). ICP analysis further indicated that 91.7% Cr3+ has been adsorbed, which is much higher than other metal ions (Figure S9).
elements.clean_text:
Adsorption of Cr3+ Ion

The existence of [(CH3)2NH2]+ cations and uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen atoms inspires us to capture heavy-metal ions in aqueous solution. Samples of 1 were immersed in 10 mL of MCl x  aqueous solutions (0.01 mol/L, M = Mg2+, Cd2+, Mn2+, Cs+, Hg2+, Cr3+, Al3+, La3+) for 24 h (Figure S6). It is noted that the color of crystals has grown green after immersing the samples in Cr3+ aqueous solutions, whereas that of other metal ions did not change. The PXRD patterns of the crystals soaked in different metal ions solutions are almost identical with that of original 1, indicating that the basic framework of 1 remains intact (Figure S7). EDS results showed the presence of these metal ions (except Cs+), which has been successfully encapsulated by 1 (Figure S8, 1-M). ICP analysis further indicated that 91.7% Cr3+ has been adsorbed, which is much higher than other metal ions (Figure S9).

elements.content: An additional experiment was performed to explore the effect of coexisting metal ions. The exchange efficiency of Cr3+ is still high and not changed much (90.6% and 88.7%) in the presence of other metal ions (Figure S10). In contrast, the exchange efficiency of other ions is still smaller (Cd2+: 64.6%, Al3+: 26.52%, La3+: 24.25%, Mn2+: 15.5%, Mg2+: 11.5%, Cs+: 7.6%, respectively). The results reveal compound 1 is a good adsorbent for Cr3+, and there is no obvious interference of coexisting metal ions.
elements.clean_text: An additional experiment was performed to explore the effect of coexisting metal ions. The exchange efficiency of Cr3+ is still high and not changed much (90.6% and 88.7%) in the presence of other metal ions (Figure S10). In contrast, the exchange efficiency of other ions is still smaller (Cd2+: 64.6%, Al3+: 26.52%, La3+: 24.25%, Mn2+: 15.5%, Mg2+: 11.5%, Cs+: 7.6%, respectively). The results reveal compound 1 is a good adsorbent for Cr3+, and there is no obvious interference of coexisting metal ions.

elements.content: Solid-state luminescent studies were conducted for free H4qptc ligand and 1 at room temperature (). Compound 1 shows enhanced blue emission peaks at 428 and 467 nm upon excitation at 362 nm, which is mainly attributed to ligand-centered electronic transitions (based n−π* and π–π* transitions) perturbed by metal ions, because similar emissions are observed at 410 and 443 nm (λex = 371 nm) for H4qptc ligand. As shown in Figure S11, the lifetime of 1 was increased to 2.85 ns from 2.03 ns (free ligand), and the quantum yield (ϕPL) is 13.50% in aqueous solution room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescent Sensing of Cr3+ Ion

Solid-state luminescent studies were conducted for free H4qptc ligand and 1 at room temperature (). Compound 1 shows enhanced blue emission peaks at 428 and 467 nm upon excitation at 362 nm, which is mainly attributed to ligand-centered electronic transitions (based n-π* and π-π* transitions) perturbed by metal ions, because similar emissions are observed at 410 and 443 nm (λex = 371 nm) for H4qptc ligand. As shown in Figure S11, the lifetime of 1 was increased to 2.85 ns from 2.03 ns (free ligand), and the quantum yield (ϕPL) is 13.50% in aqueous solution room temperature.

elements.content: (a) Solid-state luminescent spectra of H4qptc ligand (black) and 1 (blue), (b) the photographs of crystalline 1 at sunlight and UV light (365 nm).
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Solid-state luminescent spectra of H4qptc ligand (black) and 1 (blue), (b) the photographs of crystalline 1 at sunlight and UV light (365 nm).

elements.content: The remarkable fluorescence and stability of 1 encourage us to study the sensing behavior toward metal ions. Ground samples of 1 were immersed in 4 mL aqueous solutions containing various MCl x (0.01 mol/L) to form a suspension. As shown in and , all metal ions produce the quenching effect on the luminescence intensity of 1, especially added Cr3+ ions, which was able to quench almost completely. More interestingly, the luminescent intensity of 1 decreased obviously with the gradual addition of Cr3+ (Figure S13a). However, for other metal ions, the luminescent intensity does not or only slightly changes (Figure S14). The quenching effect can be quantitatively explained by the Stern–Volmer equation: I 0 /I = 1 + K sv × [Cr3+], where I and I 0 are the luminescent intensity of the solution with Cr3+ ions and the blank sample, and K sv is the quenching coefficient. The luminescence intensity of 1 has a good linear relationship with the Cr3+ concentration (R 2 = 0.991) in the range of 0–40 μM, and K sv is calculated to be 4.39 × 104 M–1 (Figure S13b).
elements.clean_text: The remarkable fluorescence and stability of 1 encourage us to study the sensing behavior toward metal ions. Ground samples of 1 were immersed in 4 mL aqueous solutions containing various MCl x  (0.01 mol/L) to form a suspension. As shown in  and , all metal ions produce the quenching effect on the luminescence intensity of 1, especially added Cr3+ ions, which was able to quench almost completely. More interestingly, the luminescent intensity of 1 decreased obviously with the gradual addition of Cr3+ (Figure S13a). However, for other metal ions, the luminescent intensity does not or only slightly changes (Figure S14). The quenching effect can be quantitatively explained by the Stern-Volmer equation: I 0 /I = 1 + K sv × [Cr3+], where I and I 0 are the luminescent intensity of the solution with Cr3+ ions and the blank sample, and K sv is the quenching coefficient. The luminescence intensity of 1 has a good linear relationship with the Cr3+ concentration (R 2 = 0.991) in the range of 0-40 μM, and K sv is calculated to be 4.39 × 104 M-1 (Figure S13b).

elements.content: Luminescent intensity of 1 in various metal ions aqueous solutions. Inset: the photos of 1–M solutions under sunlight and UV light (365 nm).
elements.clean_text: 3  Luminescent intensity of 1 in various metal ions aqueous solutions. Inset: the photos of 1-M solutions under sunlight and UV light (365 nm).

elements.content: It is important to explore the selectivity of 1 toward Cr3+, because there are various metal ions in wastewater simultaneously. As shown in , there is a negligible effect of these metal ions on the luminescence intensity of 1 except for Cr3+. However, when 20 μL of Cr3+ aqueous solution was added, the luminescent intensity of 1 decreased sharply, indicating compound 1 may be considered as a luminescent probe for Cr3+ with a detection limit of 1 μmol/L (Figure S15). The recycling experiments were investigated, because in practical application, recyclability is significant for a sensor. At first, we tried to simply wash 1–Cr3+ with deionized water, but the luminescent intensity did not recover to the original level, possibly ascribed to minimal [Me2NH2]+ being exchanged by Cr3+. Then, we attempted to use saturated KNO3 aqueous solution to immerse 1–Cr3+ into deionized water to remove K+ from the surface, which was measured by ICP to verify no Cr3+ remained in the skeleton. After the recycling experiment was implemented five times, the luminescent intensity and PXRD of the samples remain consistent with those of the original one (), which indicates that 1 may be a promising practical Cr3+ sensor.
elements.clean_text: It is important to explore the selectivity of 1 toward Cr3+, because there are various metal ions in wastewater simultaneously. As shown in , there is a negligible effect of these metal ions on the luminescence intensity of 1 except for Cr3+. However, when 20 μL of Cr3+ aqueous solution was added, the luminescent intensity of 1 decreased sharply, indicating compound 1 may be considered as a luminescent probe for Cr3+ with a detection limit of 1 μmol/L (Figure S15). The recycling experiments were investigated, because in practical application, recyclability is significant for a sensor. At first, we tried to simply wash 1-Cr3+ with deionized water, but the luminescent intensity did not recover to the original level, possibly ascribed to minimal [Me2NH2]+ being exchanged by Cr3+. Then, we attempted to use saturated KNO3 aqueous solution to immerse 1-Cr3+ into deionized water to remove K+ from the surface, which was measured by ICP to verify no Cr3+ remained in the skeleton. After the recycling experiment was implemented five times, the luminescent intensity and PXRD of the samples remain consistent with those of the original one (), which indicates that 1 may be a promising practical Cr3+ sensor.

elements.content: Metal ions selectivity of 1 in aqueous solutions (0.01 mol/L). The black bars (left) stand for the fluorescent intensity of 1 in aqueous solutions; the red bars (middle) for adding 200 μL of metal ions aqueous solutions; and the blue bars (right) for adding 20 μL of Cr3+ aqueous solution.

elements.content: We can speculate about the possible mechanism for selective detection of Cr3+ ions. From the structural point of view, there are uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen atoms in 1, which may interact with metal ions, giving rise to competition with Cr3+. The binding energy of different metal ions with oxygen atoms was performed at the DFT level by using the Amsterdam density functional (ADF2016.10) program package, which indicates Cr3+ has stronger bond ability with oxygen atom than other metal ions (Table S2). According to the theory of soft and hard acid–base, harder Lewis acids (Cr3+, Al3+, La3+, Mn2+, Mg2+ and Cs+ ions) show stronger bonding ability with the hard basic (O2–) sites (thermodynamic control), but the quenching influence of Hg2+ (softer Lewis acid) is next to Cr3+. Thus, the result of fluorescent detection may be the synergy from the metal charge, bond ability of metal ions to oxygen atom, and soft and hard acid–base properties. When 1 incorporated Cr3+ ions, the uncoordinated oxygen atoms of 1 donate electrons to Cr3+ ions (acceptor), resulting in the energy migration and luminescent quenching. It is also confirmed by the UV–vis spectra of solid 1 and 1–Cr3+. As shown in Figure S16, except for the band at 322 nm, there is a new band at 570 nm in the spectra of 1–Cr3+, which may be due to the interaction between Cr3+ ions and carboxylate groups. In order to verify whether the valence state of chromium changed, we performed the X-ray photoelectron spectrometry (XPS) of 1–Cr3+. There are two peaks at 587.3 and 577.8 eV, representing the characteristic for Cr3+ 2p1/2-O and Cr3+ 2p3/2-O, respectively (Figure S17), which suggests that chromium still remains trivalent. It also provided evidence for the interaction between Cr3+ ions and carboxylate groups.
elements.clean_text: We can speculate about the possible mechanism for selective detection of Cr3+ ions. From the structural point of view, there are uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen atoms in 1, which may interact with metal ions, giving rise to competition with Cr3+. The binding energy of different metal ions with oxygen atoms was performed at the DFT level by using the Amsterdam density functional (ADF2016.10) program package, which indicates Cr3+ has stronger bond ability with oxygen atom than other metal ions (Table S2). According to the theory of soft and hard acid-base, harder Lewis acids (Cr3+, Al3+, La3+, Mn2+, Mg2+ and Cs+ ions) show stronger bonding ability with the hard basic (O2-) sites (thermodynamic control), but the quenching influence of Hg2+ (softer Lewis acid) is next to Cr3+. Thus, the result of fluorescent detection may be the synergy from the metal charge, bond ability of metal ions to oxygen atom, and soft and hard acid-base properties. When 1 incorporated Cr3+ ions, the uncoordinated oxygen atoms of 1 donate electrons to Cr3+ ions (acceptor), resulting in the energy migration and luminescent quenching. It is also confirmed by the UV-vis spectra of solid 1 and 1-Cr3+. As shown in Figure S16, except for the band at 322 nm, there is a new band at 570 nm in the spectra of 1-Cr3+, which may be due to the interaction between Cr3+ ions and carboxylate groups. In order to verify whether the valence state of chromium changed, we performed the X-ray photoelectron spectrometry (XPS) of 1-Cr3+. There are two peaks at 587.3 and 577.8 eV, representing the characteristic for Cr3+ 2p1/2-O and Cr3+ 2p3/2-O, respectively (Figure S17), which suggests that chromium still remains trivalent. It also provided evidence for the interaction between Cr3+ ions and carboxylate groups.

elements.content: It is crucial to develop rapid detection of nitroaromatics for environmental monitoring and security screening. Taking into account the important role of solvents, aromatic and protonic solvents were selected, namely, nitrobenzene (NB), 2,4-dinitrotoluene (2,4-DNT), 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP), water, methanol, ethanol, 2-propanol, n-butanol, 1,4-dioxane, n-hexane, N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA), and acetonitrile. It is worth noting that fluorescence enhance or quench as the polarity of solvents changed, which exhibits solvent-dependent behavior at about 410 nm maximum peak (a, S18). The fluorescent intensity is dramatically different at least 100 times in DMF and nitroaromatic compound (NB, 2,4-DNT and TNP).
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescent Sensing of TNP

It is crucial to develop rapid detection of nitroaromatics for environmental monitoring and security screening. Taking into account the important role of solvents, aromatic and protonic solvents were selected, namely, nitrobenzene (NB), 2,4-dinitrotoluene (2,4-DNT), 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP), water, methanol, ethanol, 2-propanol, n-butanol, 1,4-dioxane, n-hexane, N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA), and acetonitrile. It is worth noting that fluorescence enhance or quench as the polarity of solvents changed, which exhibits solvent-dependent behavior at about 410 nm maximum peak (a, S18). The fluorescent intensity is dramatically different at least 100 times in DMF and nitroaromatic compound (NB, 2,4-DNT and TNP).

elements.content: (a) Luminescent intensity, (b) photographs of 1 in different solvents at sunlight and UV light (λ = 365 nm), (c) comparison of the quenching efficiency for three nitro-explosives, (d) emission spectra of 1 dispersed in DMF upon addition of TNP (1 mmol/L) solution. Inset: fluorescent photographs of the original and with TNP.
elements.clean_text: 6  (a) Luminescent intensity, (b) photographs of 1 in different solvents at sunlight and UV light (λ = 365 nm), (c) comparison of the quenching efficiency for three nitro-explosives, (d) emission spectra of 1 dispersed in DMF upon addition of TNP (1 mmol/L) solution. Inset: fluorescent photographs of the original and with TNP.

elements.content: To further compare the sensing abilities of 1 toward nitroaromatics, fluorescent titration experiments were investigated in DMF suspension of 1 by addition of nitroaromatics solutions (1 mmol/L, NB, 2,4-DNT, and TNP). The color of solution changed immediately from colorless to pale yellow upon addition of TNP, which could be easily observed by the naked eye (b), maybe due to the strong interaction between TNP and 1. Compared with NB and 2,4-DNT solution (quenching efficiency of 23.5% and 6%, Figure S19), compound 1 shows very high quenching efficiency of 93.05% after adding 8 μL of TNP solution (c). Fluorescence quenching of 8.29% can be observed even adding 2 μL of 0.1 mmol/L of TNP (Figure S20), demonstrating 1 can selectively sense trace amount of TNP.
elements.clean_text: To further compare the sensing abilities of 1 toward nitroaromatics, fluorescent titration experiments were investigated in DMF suspension of 1 by addition of nitroaromatics solutions (1 mmol/L, NB, 2,4-DNT, and TNP). The color of solution changed immediately from colorless to pale yellow upon addition of TNP, which could be easily observed by the naked eye (b), maybe due to the strong interaction between TNP and 1. Compared with NB and 2,4-DNT solution (quenching efficiency of 23.5% and 6%, Figure S19), compound 1 shows very high quenching efficiency of 93.05% after adding 8 μL of TNP solution (c). Fluorescence quenching of 8.29% can be observed even adding 2 μL of 0.1 mmol/L of TNP (Figure S20), demonstrating 1 can selectively sense trace amount of TNP.

elements.content: To investigate the mechanism for the selective sensing of TNP, the quenching efficiency was analyzed by using the Stern–Volmer equation, F 0 /F = 1 + K sv[C] (K sv is the quenching coefficient). From the linear fitting of the plot (Figure S21), the quenching constant was found to be 2.08 × 106 M–1, which is higher than that of the current maximum value (5.10 × 105 M–1) (Table S3). The average lifetime was unchanged even after the addition of TNP (Figure S22), which indicates that the quenching process follows static mechanism. From the UV–vis spectra, we found that a new band at 350 nm appeared upon addition of TNP, but there is negligible change for those of 2,4-DNT and NB (Figure S23). In addition, it displays the maximum overlap between the absorption spectrum of TNP and the emission spectrum of 1 (Figure S24). Therefore, from nonlinearity of the Stern–Volmer plot and the spectral overlap of TNP with 1, the selective fluorescence quenching is attributed to the energy transfer and the electron transfer mechanism.
elements.clean_text: To investigate the mechanism for the selective sensing of TNP, the quenching efficiency was analyzed by using the Stern-Volmer equation, F 0 /F = 1 + K sv[C] (K sv is the quenching coefficient). From the linear fitting of the plot (Figure S21), the quenching constant was found to be 2.08 × 106 M-1, which is higher than that of the current maximum value (5.10 × 105 M-1) (Table S3). The average lifetime was unchanged even after the addition of TNP (Figure S22), which indicates that the quenching process follows static mechanism. From the UV-vis spectra, we found that a new band at 350 nm appeared upon addition of TNP, but there is negligible change for those of 2,4-DNT and NB (Figure S23). In addition, it displays the maximum overlap between the absorption spectrum of TNP and the emission spectrum of 1 (Figure S24). Therefore, from nonlinearity of the Stern-Volmer plot and the spectral overlap of TNP with 1, the selective fluorescence quenching is attributed to the energy transfer and the electron transfer mechanism.

elements.content: In summary, a stable fluorescent 3D anionic MOF with atn topology has been successfully synthesized, which is constructed by rod-shaped Zn4(trz)2 chain SBUs and π-electron-rich qptc4– linkers. Remarkably, it displays highly selective capture and visual sensing of heavy-metal Cr3+ ion in aqueous solutions, which can be recyclable. Meanwhile, the selective sensing of TNP contaminant has a large K sv of 2.08 × 106 M–1. The study opened up a promising approach to design and prepare MOF-based multifunctional sensor, which is likely to be useful under more realistic conditions in the future.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, a stable fluorescent 3D anionic MOF with atn topology has been successfully synthesized, which is constructed by rod-shaped Zn4(trz)2 chain SBUs and π-electron-rich qptc4- linkers. Remarkably, it displays highly selective capture and visual sensing of heavy-metal Cr3+ ion in aqueous solutions, which can be recyclable. Meanwhile, the selective sensing of TNP contaminant has a large K sv of 2.08 × 106 M-1. The study opened up a promising approach to design and prepare MOF-based multifunctional sensor, which is likely to be useful under more realistic conditions in the future.

cln_elements.content: A mixture of H4qptc (0.040 g, 0.10 mmol), Zn­(OAc)2·6H2O (0.045 g, 0.20 mmol), 1,2,4-triazole (0.007 g, 0.10 mmol), DMF (4 mL), and H2O (2 mL) were stirred and adjusted to pH = 6 by dropwise addition of 8 M HNO3 solution, then sealed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless autoclave at 140 °C for 5 days. After it was slowly cooled to room temperature and filtrated, colorless cuboid block crystals of 1 were collected (yield of 85% based on Zn). Anal. Calcd (%) for C41H27N8O15Zn3 (1): C, 46.11; H, 2.55; N, 10.49. Found: C, 46.20; H, 2.25; N, 10.70. IR data (Figure S1, KBr pellet, cm–1): 3436 (s), 3129 (w), 2791 (w), 2477 (w), 1595 (s), 1379 (s), 1154 (s), 1078 (w), 852 (w), 782 (w), 677 (w). The crystal data are given in , whereas selected bond lengths and bond angles are given in Table S1.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis of [Me2NH2]4[Zn6(qptc)3(trz)4]⋅6H2O (1)

A mixture of H4qptc (0.040 g, 0.10 mmol), Zn(OAc)2⋅6H2O (0.045 g, 0.20 mmol), 1,2,4-triazole (0.007 g, 0.10 mmol), DMF (4 mL), and H2O (2 mL) were stirred and adjusted to pH = 6 by dropwise addition of 8 M HNO3 solution, then sealed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless autoclave at 140 °C for 5 days. After it was slowly cooled to room temperature and filtrated, colorless cuboid block crystals of 1 were collected (yield of 85% based on Zn). Anal. Calcd (%) for C41H27N8O15Zn3 (1): C, 46.11; H, 2.55; N, 10.49. Found: C, 46.20; H, 2.25; N, 10.70. IR data (Figure S1, KBr pellet, cm-1): 3436 (s), 3129 (w), 2791 (w), 2477 (w), 1595 (s), 1379 (s), 1154 (s), 1078 (w), 852 (w), 782 (w), 677 (w). The crystal data are given in , whereas selected bond lengths and bond angles are given in Table S1.

cln_elements.content:
The phase purity of the samples 1 was confirmed by PXRD patterns. Most peak positions of simulated and experimental patterns are in good agreement with each other. To further investigate the stability of 1, it was immersed in different pH values aqueous solutions or water at 75 °C. The PXRD patterns indicated that the structure is retained after soaked in water at 75 °C and pH = 2–10 aqueous solutions (Figure S5), confirming the strong chemical stability, which is ascribed to the strong Zn–N bonds (triazole). TGA of 1 was performed at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1 to estimate the thermal stability in air. As shown in Figure S3, the first weight loss of 8.22% within 102 °C belongs to the loss of lattice water molecules. The second weight loss of 35.25% in the range of 102–400 °C is in agreement with the removal of triazole and qptc4– ligand, accompanied by the decomposition of the framework. The final residue of 15.01% is close to the percentage of zinc oxide (calcd 17.78%).

Fluorescent Sensing of Cr<sup>3+</sup> Ion

Solid-state luminescent studies were conducted for free H4qptc ligand and 1 at room temperature (). Compound 1 shows enhanced blue emission peaks at 428 and 467 nm upon excitation at 362 nm, which is mainly attributed to ligand-centered electronic transitions (based n−π* and π–π* transitions) perturbed by metal ions, because similar emissions are observed at 410 and 443 nm (λex = 371 nm) for H4qptc ligand. As shown in Figure S11, the lifetime of 1 was increased to 2.85 ns from 2.03 ns (free ligand), and the quantum yield (ϕPL) is 13.50% in aqueous solution room temperature.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Stability of 1 

The phase purity of the samples 1 was confirmed by PXRD patterns. Most peak positions of simulated and experimental patterns are in good agreement with each other. To further investigate the stability of 1, it was immersed in different pH values aqueous solutions or water at 75 °C. The PXRD patterns indicated that the structure is retained after soaked in water at 75 °C and pH = 2-10 aqueous solutions (Figure S5), confirming the strong chemical stability, which is ascribed to the strong Zn-N bonds (triazole). TGA of 1 was performed at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 to estimate the thermal stability in air. As shown in Figure S3, the first weight loss of 8.22% within 102 °C belongs to the loss of lattice water molecules. The second weight loss of 35.25% in the range of 102-400 °C is in agreement with the removal of triazole and qptc4- ligand, accompanied by the decomposition of the framework. The final residue of 15.01% is close to the percentage of zinc oxide (calcd 17.78%).

Fluorescent Sensing of Cr3+ Ion

Solid-state luminescent studies were conducted for free H4qptc ligand and 1 at room temperature (). Compound 1 shows enhanced blue emission peaks at 428 and 467 nm upon excitation at 362 nm, which is mainly attributed to ligand-centered electronic transitions (based n-π* and π-π* transitions) perturbed by metal ions, because similar emissions are observed at 410 and 443 nm (λex = 371 nm) for H4qptc ligand. As shown in Figure S11, the lifetime of 1 was increased to 2.85 ns from 2.03 ns (free ligand), and the quantum yield (ϕPL) is 13.50% in aqueous solution room temperature.

decomposition temperature.type: removal of triazole and qptc4- ligand, decomposition of the framework
